canvases.label: Chronolgy of Ancient Nations, f.10v detail

metadata.value: Detail of image from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Allegedly depicts a passage from Isiah 21, presenting it as a prophecy about Muhammad: shown riding on a camel next to Christ, who is riding a donkey, Al-Biruni asserts that the Prophet's arrival at the watchman's tower announced the destruction of Babylon. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. A free online copy of this translation can be found via the following link: https://archive.org/details/chronologyofanci00biru. Sources: http://www.ucl.ac.uk/hebrew-jewish/research/research-pro/calendars-antiquity-middle-ages/al-biruni (accessed 06/06/14). Chelkowski, P. J. (1975), 'The scholar and the saint : studies in commemoration of Abuʾl-Rayhan al-Biruni and Jalal al-Din al-Rumi', New York.

metadata.value: Isaiah's prophecy about Muhammad Al-Biruni takes a passage from Isaiah chapter twenty-one, and presents it as a prophecy about Muhammad. In this chapter, God ordered Isaiah to place a watchman in a tower, who reports that he saw the Messiah riding on a donkey, and Muhammad riding on a camel, announcing the destruction of Babylon. This image illustrates the watchman in the tower, the Prophet riding on a camel, and the Messiah riding on a donkey, gesturing towards Muhammad as if to indicate his arrival has fulfilled the prophecy about Babylon.

metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Central image depicts the birth of Augustus, the first Roman Emperor, via a primitive form of Caesarean Section. According to Al-Biruni, he was delivered by this method after his mother died during labour. In the centre of the image, a doctor removes the infant head-first from an incision in Atia Balba's abdomen, while three other figures look on from the side. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image depicts the death of Mani, the founder of Manichaeism, an Iranian Gnostic religion that gained widespread popularity during the late antique and Medieval periods. Showing Mani's severed head suspended on a gate, with body lying below, the painting appears to be an amalgamation of the two stories regarding Mani's death which are present in Al-Biruni's manuscript: in the first, the prophet's flayed skin is filled with grass and attached to the gate of Gundishapur, while in the second, he is decapitated and his body exposed in the street. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image shows Bihafarid, a religious leader from Iran, convincing a peasant to join his sect by telling him that he has just returned from heaven and has been given Green garment as proof of his trip. Combining elements of Zoroastrianism and Islam, Bihafarid's sect, which developed following a trip to China, naturally faced opposition from both religious groups. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image shows Al-Hallaj, who according to Al-Biruni predicted the imminent arrival of the Mahdi, just moments before his execution in Baghdad. He had already been subjected to one thousand lashes, while his limbs had also been removed. Seen staring into the eyes of his executioner, who is about to decapitate him before his body is burned, the stumps of his legs are still bleeding, while one of the severed limbs is lying underneath his shoulder. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image shows an individual from the Ibn Abi Zakariyya religious group being punished for sodomy. Depicted lying face down with his arms and feet bound, the surrounding text explains that the punishment for such behaviour was to be dragged face down for eighteen metres. As such, the figure on the right can be seen holding a rope connected to the victim's feet, while a cloud of dust above him indicates movement. According to Al-Biruni, although Sodomy was forbidden by the group, intercourse with boys was encouraged. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image shows an enthroned ruler with attendants on his left. The figure on the far right holding his hands to the sky may be representative of a ritual where an individual would stand in the courtyard of a royal residence at dawn and invite angels to come down from the sky to aid men in combating evil forces, as this practice is mentioned in the manuscript. Alternatively, this scene could also reflect the custom of rulers holding an audience on the occasion of the Mihrjan. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image depicts Dahhak, who is bound and on his knees, addressing the mythical king Faridun, the enthroned individual to the left of the image. According to the associated text, Dahhak is asking Faridun if he is seeking revenge for the death of his ancestor. Faridun replies that Dahhak is not worthy of such a fate, and that he will instead be punished for the death of a cow belonging to the Faridun family. The portrayal of Dahhak as a white-bearded man with two snakes growing from his shoulders was a convention popular at the time of the image's production. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image at base shows Adam and Eve (left) eating with the spirit of Abel. Scene is said to be representative of the festival of Farwardijan, where families would leave food for the dead in cemeteries and on the roofs of their houses, due to the belief that the dead would return to their old surroundings. In this particular example, Abel is said to have stayed with Adam and Eve for ten days, although he was unable to speak during this time. The gestures exhibited by the figures in this image may represent an attempt to try and overcome this problem Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image shows four figures drinking and roasting fowl around a fire, while birds fly above. Scene is likely to represent the festival of the Bahman Mah, in which rulers, having lit fires, would drive small animals and birds into the flames, before asking Goda to seek revenge on those tormenting harmless creatures. Prior to the fires being lit, the creatures which were to be burnt would be soaked in napatha, so they would catch light as soon as the fires were kindled, effectively becoming moving flames against the wind or, in the case of the birds, flying torches. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image shows the rooftops of a village blazing with fires, while two figures look on, and probably depicts the tale of Azmaa. Although charged with providing the brains for Dahhak's snakes to eat, Azmaa would only kill half of the intended victims, sending the rest to live on Mount Dermavand. When Dahhak died however, he was indicted for his part in the murders and so to prove that he was innocent, having saved a large number of victims, he ordered all those whom he had freed to light fires on their roofs so they could be counted. This number turned out to be so great that, rather than being executed, Azmaa was given a fief instead. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image shows Zoroastrian priests on the right, being questioned by the Sasanian ruler, Peroz, the enthroned figure on the left, who had come to the fire temple to pray for the end of a drought which had lasted for several years. Having completed his prayers, but ignored by the temple officials, he retired to another part of the temple, where he asked the priests why they had previously refused to greet him. Explaining that it would have ben improper to address him in the presence of a god, they placated him. As Peroz set out for home, it started to rain, indicating that his prayers had been granted. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image shows individuals gathering at a place of worship to celebrate the Autumnal Equinox in India, according to custom. Interestingly, although this scene is set in India, the place of worship is not recognisably Hindu or Buddhist, while the religion of the figures themselves is not portrayed by the artistic conventions which were used to differentiate Hindus or Muslims during the thirteenth and fourteenth century. As such, it is possible that the painter of this scene has substituted a sheikh and his disciples for the Indians worshipping. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. A free online copy of this translation can be found via the following link: https://archive.org/details/chronologyofanci00biru. Sources: http://www.ucl.ac.uk/hebrew-jewish/research/research-pro/calendars-antiquity-middle-ages/al-biruni (accessed 06/06/14). Chelkowski, P. J. (1975), 'The scholar and the saint: studies in commemoration of Abuʾl-Rayhan al-Biruni and Jalal al-Din al-Rumi', New York.
metadata.label: Description

metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image shows Eli, portrayed in Mongol dress, lying dead at the foot of a throne which is also associated with Mongol culture, perhaps indicating how the artist portrayed non-Muslims throughout the manuscript. The text surrounding the image describes the death of Eli after hearing about the loss of the Ark of the Covenant, although it is highly abbreviated. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image shows the destruction of Bayt al-Muqaddas, understood to be the Solomonic temple at Jerusalem, by fire at the hands of King Bukhtnassar (also known as Nebuchadnezzar), with the outer wall and dome being consumed by flames at the centre of the image. On either side, a figure can be seen aiding the destruction, the individual on the right possibly being Bukhtnassar himself. In the text, Al-Biruni mentions that this event was commemorated by fasting on the ninth day of the month of Ab. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image shows Jesus Christ standing in the waters of the River Jordan, about to be baptised. John the Baptist is standing at the water's edge, holding Christ's white garment, while his sandals are floating on the surface of the river. a dove can be scene descending towards the two, but the image lacks the sense of familiarity, suggesting that the artist lacked a previous knowledge of the baptism scene Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. metadata.value: Detail of page of the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image depicts the Annunciation, in which Mary was informed of the coming of Christ, her son,by the angel Gabriel. Mary is shown sitting cross-legged at the left of the image, with Gabriel on the right, gesturing towards her. The fact that Mary is weaving on an Islamic frame suggests that this image is derived from the Byzantine tradition of Christ: while Muslims do not accept Christ's divinity, his immaculate conception is considered truthful and is even mentioned in the Qur'an. metadata.value: Detail of page of the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image several figures sitting in tents, including an old woman watching a mother nursing her child on the left; a man eating while a woman prepares food in the centre and a woman standing holding a drinking vessel on the right. Scene is believed to depict the fair of Ukaz, a community in the vicinity of Makkah (Mecca), which is mentioned in the text. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image depicts the prophet Muhammad and his family addressing the Christians of Najran, who are situated on the far left, on the Day of the Cursing. As well as marking the occasion where Muhammad exchanged curses with the Christians of Najran, this is also the day on which the prophet named Hassan and Hussain as his sons, Fatima as his wife, and Abu Talib as his most intimate friend. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. metadata.value: Detail of page from the Chronology of Ancient Nations by Al-Biruni. Image shows the investiture of Ali by the prophet Muhammad, as he encourages Muslims to transfer their support to him at the end of his Farewell Pilgrimage. In this scene, the prophet can be seen with his hand on Ali's shoulder, while three spectators look on from either side. This references a popular tradition of linking individuals through ties stronger than marriage or kinship and is as much an affirmation of the pair's eternal friendship as securing Ali's position within the Muslim community. Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. metadata.value: Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. metadata.value: Written by the famous astronomer and polymath Abu Rayhan Al-Biruni, the Chronology of Ancient Nations is a compendium and chronicle of a vast number of calendars and chronological systems from a variety of different cultural and religious groups from throughout the late antique and medieval periods in the Hellenic world, Central Asia and the Near East. Completed in the year 1000, it even includes details of festivals and liturgical practices, in addition to more specific information. This particular manuscript is thought to have been copied in 1307 and was the archetype for the three later versions which were used by Edward Sachau to translate the document from Arabic into English during the nineteenth century. A free online copy of this translation can be found via the following link: https://archive.org…Sources: http://www.ucl.ac.u…(accessed 06/06/14). Chelkowski, P. J. (1975), 'The scholar and the saint: studies in commemoration of Abuʾl-Rayhan al-Biruni and Jalal al-Din al-Rumi', New York.
